Appendix:
For more information on NanoString GeoMx technology visit our [**website**](https://www.nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/geomx-dsp-overview/).

Details of the performance of WTA have been [**published**](https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.09.29.462442).

Minerva is an open-source software package that was developed by Laboratory of Systems Pharmacology at Harvard University and is available [**here**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki).

We would like to thank Jeremy Muhlich and John Thomas Hoffer for assistance in enabling Minerva features to support the Spatial Organ Atlas.

Stories.Description:
Welcome to the [**Spatial Organ Atlas (SOA)**](https://www.nanostring.com/spatial-organ-atlas) Human Brain Demonstration.

The SOA is a database for whole transcriptome spatial profiles of functional components of tissues from human and mouse generated with the GeoMx® Digital Spatial Profiler. All the data in the SOA is downloadable, including [**this human brain sample (#001)**](https://nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/spatial-organ-atlas/human-brain/).

Using [**Minerva**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki), we will show you how the imaging and molecular data combine to give you a comprehensive profile of the tissue architecture and biology.

Click around to explore on your own. 

Hints:
* Zoom and pan the image via the mouse/trackpad. Dependent on browser and operating system, keyboard shortcuts are available: + zoom in, - zoom out, pan via arrow keys (tested on Chrome).
* Open and close the left- and right-hand menus by clicking on < or >.
* See results in the left-hand menu and click on the selectable regions to zoom to the featured area of the tissue.
* Turn channels on and off with the right-hand menu.

Waypoints.Name: Gross Brain Anatomy
Waypoints.Description:
The brain is the most complex organ in the human body, containing about 170 billion cells which work collectively to regulate the body, interpret information from the outside world, and drive behavior. [**(Azevedo et al. 2009)**](https://doi.org/10.1002/cne.21974)

This section through the medial temporal lobe contains the hippocampus, along with surrounding areas of cerebral cortex and subcortical white matter. The hippocampus is part of the limbic system with important roles in learning and memory. The cerebral cortex is associated with higher order cognitive functions including decision making, thought and emotion and the subcortical white matter enables communication between different regions of the brain. If you select a region on the cartoon, it will be highlighted on the image.

With GeoMx DSP, regions of interest (ROIs) are selected by the user and then molecularly profiled. These ROIs can be either profiled in entirety (i.e., geometric profiling) or subdivided based on the visible morphology markers into compartments and profiled separately (i.e., segmented profiling). The segmented profiling we have carried out is:

* NeuN+ (Neuronal nuclei and perinuclear cytoplasm)
* NeuN- (Neuropil)
* Iba1+ (Microglia)
* GFAP (Astrocytes)
* Syto83 (Nuclei)

Using these morphology markers, we assessed eight different structures and collected 20 total ROI types, a subset of which were segmented using those markers.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* You can toggle the ROIs that were molecularly profiled by clicking on the respective data layers (left-hand side of screen).
* Because of the large number of ROIs, there is a new category, “All data layers”. Selecting this allows you to toggle between selecting all data layers and selecting no data layers. Thus, a single click can unselect all data layers, allowing easy selection of a single data layer.
* You can change the morphology markers being displayed by selecting channel groups - all markers or individual markers can be displayed. Switching to an individual marker can make it easier to see small or complex ROIs.

Waypoints.Name: Detailed Brain Anatomy
Waypoints.Description: With GeoMx DSP, regions of interest (ROIs) are selected by the user and then molecularly profiled. These ROIs can be either profiled whole (i.e., geometric profiling) or subdivided based on the visible morphology markers into compartments and profiled separately (i.e., segmented profiling). In the cartoon below, the layers of the cortex profiled are highlighted with red outlines. Selecting each layer will show a typical ROI from the respective layer in the tissue image. In cortical layer V, select the features outlined in red within the cartoon to see an example of each segment type: NeuN+ (orange in cartoon), Iba1+ (purple in cartoon), and GFAP+ (cyan in cartoon).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:

* Select a single layer on the diagram to see an example of the corresponding ROIs.
* Adding Cortical layer V data layers in combination from the list on the left will allow you to see how the segmented profiling strategy can be used to optically dissect an ROI.

Waypoints.Name: Linking Molecular and Imaging Data 1
Waypoints.Description: One of the key aspects of spatial biology is the ability to link molecular and spatial (image) data. In this figure, the average number of genes detected per ROI by structure is shown. We show the number of genes per geometric ROI. The number of genes seen per ROI tracks with neural density, with the lowest number observed in cortical layer I, which is defined by its absence of neural cells.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select a data point to see its corresponding ROI.

axis.labelExpr: datum.label == 1 ? 'Cortical layer I' : datum.label == 2 ? 'Cortical layer II/III' : datum.label == 3 ? 'Cortical layer IV' : datum.label == 4 ? 'Cortical layer V' : datum.label == 5 ? 'Cortical white matter' : datum.label == 6 ? 'Hippocampus CA1' : datum.label == 7 ? 'Hippocampus dentate gyrus' : null

Waypoints.Name: Linking Molecular and Imaging Data 2
Waypoints.Description: In this analysis we only assess segmented ROI. All data are separated by segmentation marker and coded by ROI location.  Here, the neuron segments (NeuN+) express considerably more genes than glial cells (GFAP+ and Iba1+) and the neuropil (NeuN-) segments. This is consistent with single cell RNA-seq datasets showing that neurons express higher numbers of genes compared to other cell types in human cortex [**(Darmanis et al. 2015)**](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1507125112). This has also been demonstrated for the mouse cortex and hippocampus [**(Zeisel et al. 2015,**](https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaa1934) [**Tasic et al. 2016).**](https://doi.org/10.1038/nn.4216)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select a single data point to be taken to that ROI.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.

Waypoints.Name: Spatial Mapping of Genes
Waypoints.Description:
Whole transcriptome profiling allows us to spatially map functional gene expression. This heatmap shows relative expression of various genes in different segmented ROIs. The expression profiles of the NeuN+ segments are strikingly distinct from the glial and neuropil segments in this heatmap of top differentially expressed genes.

Nearly all genes we identified as neuron-enriched relative to glia in this experiment (*CADM3*, *YWHAG*, *UCHL1*, *SNAP25*, etc.) were also present within the top ranked neuron-enriched genes from a meta-analysis of human and murine brain RNA-seq datasets [**(McKenzie et al. 2018)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-27293-5). The enrichment of genes, such as *NDRG2* and *CST3*, in non-neuronal cell types is also consistent with previous datasets [**(McKenzie et al. 2018).**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-27293-5)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Hold mouse over the main body of heatmap to show the gene that a row corresponds to.
* Hold mouse over the bottom key bar to identify a specific ROI.
* Click on a column to zoom in on the corresponding ROI on the image.  Select the “All data layers” button to see how much segmentation is possible.

labelColor.expr: datum.value === 'CADM3' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'UCHL1' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'YWHAG' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'SNAP25' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'NDRG2' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'CST3' ? '#00c5c8' : 'white'

Waypoints.Name: Spatial Mapping of Genes Excluding Neuron-Rich ROIs
Waypoints.Description:
Differences between non-neuronal populations profiled can be further elucidated by removing NeuN+ segments from the analysis. By removing NeuN+ segments from the differential expression analysis, we can see that the top differentially expressed genes are well-established as expressed in microglia, astrocytes or the neuropil.

*AQP4*, *GJA1*, *CPE*, *CLU*, *GLUL* are enriched in astrocytes, consistent with human and murine transcriptome-wide RNA expression datasets examining brain cell type-specific gene expression [**(McKenzie et al. 2018)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-27293-5). *AIF1* (Iba1), *TYROBP*, *CD68*, *P2RY12*, *C1QB*, *C1QC*, and *CD74* are also all enriched in microglia as expected [**(McKenzie et al. 2018)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-27293-5). Moreover, the neuropil exhibits enrichment of genes like voltage-gated calcium channel *CACNG2*, the expression of which has previously been shown in CA1 hippocampal dendrites [**(Cajigas et al. 2012).**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2012.02.036)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Hold mouse over the main body of heatmap to show the gene that a row corresponds to.
* Hold mouse over the bottom key bar to identify a specific ROI.
* Click on a column to zoom in on the corresponding ROI on the image.  Select the “All data layers” button to see how much segmentation is possible.

labelColor.expr: datum.value === 'AQP4' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'GJA1' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'CPE' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'CLU' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'GLUL' ? '#FF4545' : datum.value === 'AIF1' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'TYROBP' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'CD68' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'P2RY12' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'C1QB' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'C1QC' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'CD74' ? '#00c5c8' : datum.value === 'CACNG2' ? '#40C000' : 'white'

Waypoints.Name: Differential Gene Expression
Waypoints.Description: In this analysis, we compare gene expression between the neurons of the hippocampal CA1 region to the densely packed neurons of the dentate gyrus. We can see a number of genes that are differentially expressed, including *SEMA5A* and *MET*, both of which have been identified as risk factors for autism spectrum disorders [**(Weiss et al. 2009,**](https://doi.org/10.1038/nature08490) [**Geschwind and Levitt 2007,**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conb.2007.01.009) [**Campbell et al. 2007)**](https://doi.org/10.1002/ana.21180). *SEMA5A* has been shown to inhibit dentate granule cell synaptogenesis in early postnatal development and into adulthood [**(Duan et al. 2014)**](https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.04390). Alternatively, the *MET* receptor tyrosine kinase is primarily expressed by CA1 neurons in the hippocampus [**(Judson et al., 2009,**](https://doi.org/10.1002/cne.21969) [**2011)**](https://doi.org/10.1093/cercor/bhq223) and facilitates developmental synaptic plasticity [**(Ma et al. 2019)**](https://doi.org/10.1002/dneu.22645).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select the regions on the graph with the genes that are differentially expressed to see all the ROIs where those genes are more highly expressed.
* Turning on only a single channel may help you see smaller ROIs.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Gene Expression with Protein Expression 1
Waypoints.Description:
We explored the relationship between our data and the [**Human Protein Atlas**](https://www.proteinatlas.org/) to investigate whether the gene expression patterns we observed would correspond to existing protein data. Here we see expression of the *NECAB1* gene alongside the IHC for the corresponding protein. The protein is expressed in neural bodies, which correlates well to the observed gene expression in NeuN+ segments.

*NECAB1* is part of the NECAB family [**(Sugita et al. 2002)**](https://doi.org/10.1016/S0306-4522(02)00063-5) of calcium binding proteins expressed in neurons, the expression of which is restricted to specific subsets of neurons.

![image](img/Necab1.jpg)

[*Image credit: Human Protein Atlas.*](https://images.proteinatlas.org/23629/156229_B_8_5_medium.jpg)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select a single data point to be taken to that ROI.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Gene Expression with Protein Expression 2
Waypoints.Description:
In further validation of our data with the [**Human Protein Atlas**](https://www.proteinatlas.org/), we find increased expression of the *GJA1* gene in the GFAP+ segments, which matches the staining pattern of the corresponding protein (also known as connexin 43) in brain as seen in the IHC image from the HPA. This transmembrane protein is upregulated in astrocytes and helps to organize plastic networks by forming hemichannels and gap junctions [**(Droguerre et al. 2019)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-54858-9).

![image](img/Gja1.png)

[*Image credit: Human Protein Atlas.*](https://images.proteinatlas.org/35097/98855_B_7_7.jpg)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select a single data point to be taken to that ROI.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Gene Expression with Protein Expression 3
Waypoints.Description:
Continuing to validate our data with the [**Human Protein Atlas**](https://www.proteinatlas.org/), we studied the relationship between expression of the CD74 protein as localized by the HPA and the expression of *CD74* in our data. CD74 is a component of the MHC Class II complex, and consequently its expression should be restricted to antigen presenting cells. As expected, the CD74 protein is localized to microglia (Iba1+ segmented ROI) within the hippocampus, the cerebral cortex, and the cerebellum.  

![image](img/CD74.jpg)

[*Image credit: Human Protein Atlas.*](https://images.proteinatlas.org/10592/26064_B_9_5_medium.jpg)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select a single data point to be taken to that ROI.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.
